channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Top U.S. Military Official Seeks to Assure Israeli on Security
item.description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told his Israeli hosts that the United States would strengthen their arsenal.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: ISIS Proves Its Persistence With Attacks in Libya and Iraq
item.description: In Libya, the Islamic State captured a critical power plant, while in Iraq, gunmen in suicide vests attacked a council building in Amiriyat al Falluja, southwest of Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Roger Vergé, a Founder of Nouvelle Cuisine, Dies at 85
item.description: His adaptation of Provençal cooking incorporated the flavors of Africa and the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:credit: Mike Slaughter/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Roger Vergé preparing a lobster dish in 1979.

item.title: West Bank Site May Pose Challenge for Netanyahu and Region’s Future
item.description: Leftist Israeli politicians and advocacy groups say a 9.5-acre property, tied to the Jewish-American philanthropist Irving Moskowitz, is part of a secret initiative to establish a new settlement.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renovations have started at a 9.5-acre compound in the West Bank that started as a church-run hospital in the 1950s and later became a hostel for travelers.

item.title: Supreme Court Backs White House on Jerusalem Passport Dispute
item.description: The justices, ruling 6 to 3, rejected an attempt by Congress to require the State Department to indicate in passports that Jerusalem is part of Israel.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK
item.media:description: Ari Zivotofsky and his son, Menachem, in Washington last fall. The boy’s passport listed his birthplace as Jerusalem, not Israel.

item.title: Belgium Commemorates Waterloo With Euro, and France Is Not Pleased
item.description: The Belgians were less victors over Napoleon than hosts to the defeat that ended his ambitions, but they have minted a new coin to celebrate the day.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The newly minted 2.50 euro coin at the Belgian Royal Mint in Brussels.

item.title: Paris Journal: An Audacious Project, and Its Founder, Slide Toward Failure in Paris
item.description: Financial problems and questions about the lead developer’s wealth have undermined a much-publicized plan for chic restaurants and shops in the Marais neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The corner of Rue de Vertbois, an artery of the Jeune Rue project.

item.title: South Korea to Focus on Pneumonia Patients Amid Bid to Contain MERS
item.description: The government said it would interview the patients and check their medical records to see if they had recently visited any of the hospitals where the infection had been found.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Wearing protective masks in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday. The spread of MERS in South Korea is the biggest reported outside Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Unveiling Third Reich Art
item.description: The recent recovery of looted sculptures raises a question: Should Germany build a museum of Nazi art?
item.dc:creator: GILES MACDONOGH
item.media:description: Sculptures that adorned Hitler’s Chancellery were recovered in a police raid last month.

item.title: Pensions in Greece Feel the Pinch of Debt Negotiations
item.description: As it confronts its creditors, the left-wing government in Athens faces few more daunting problems than how to meet the promises it has made to retirees.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vasiliki Meliou retired at 53 after the state-owned bank she worked for was sold.

item.title: Al Qaeda Works With Local Insurgents, in Tactical Shift
item.description: The strategy allows the group to build local support while providing some cover against the threat of foreign military action.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Women’s Rights Battle, a Call to Underarms
item.description: Xiao Meili is conducting a photo contest to challenge a growing belief in China that a woman must have hair-free armpits to be attractive.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Xiao Meili, who organized the contest to fight social pressure for women to shave their armpits, posted her own photo.

item.title: Growing Body of Law Allows Prosecution of Foreign Citizens on U.S. Soil
item.description: In terrorism cases, the broadening of a key law, the splintering of terrorist groups and a shift away from military detention has led to the prosecutions in federal courts.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The federal courthouse in Brooklyn. Perhaps no federal prosecutor was more aggressive about expanding her office’s global reach than Loretta E. Lynch when she was the United States attorney in the borough.

item.title: Op-Docs: ‘The Art of Dissent’
item.description: The filmmaker Laura Poitras documents the dissidents Ai Weiwei and Jacob Appelbaum as they collaborate on an art project.
item.dc:creator: LAURA POITRAS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Macedonia at the Crossroads
item.description: The Balkan nation is in crisis. Will it manage to reform itself, or will it follow its former Yugoslavian neighbors into crisis?
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Police in Eastern India Say They Killed 12 Maoist Rebels
item.description: A prominent rebel commander, Anurag Ji, was among those who died in the gunfight early Tuesday, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Creating a Market for Refugees in Europe
item.description: How a ‘cap and trade’ system would be more humanitarian.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: PETER H. SCHUCK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Rapper’s Ode to Uber, Chengdu Gangster Style
item.description: After Uber drivers protested a crackdown by the local traffic police in Chengdu, China, a student and amateur hip-hop artist vented his frustration about Uber’s troubles in his favorite form: gangster rap.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uber faces many hurdles in China, where the market is highly competitive, regulated and, at times, eccentric.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ai Weiwei Trades Politics for Subtlety in First Solo Exhibition in China
item.description: Tourists, fans, and family and friends of the artist flocked to the opening the exhibition to see the show and, more important for many, to catch a glimpse of Mr. Ai.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: The installation of an ancestral hall from Jiangxi Province in adjoining galleries forms part of Ai Weiwei's exhibition.

item.title: Earthquake Prods Nepal Parties to Make Constitution Deal
item.description: They agreed to a federal model with eight provinces that would allow them to form a government and rebuild the quake-ravaged nation.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and ELLEN BARRY
